Use when creating routes, controllers, services, repositories, middleware, or working with Express APIs, Prisma database access, Sentry error tracking, Zod validation, unifiedConfig, dependency injection, or async patterns. Covers layered architecture (routes → controllers → services → repositories), BaseController pattern, error handling, performance monitoring, testing strategies, and migration from legacy patterns.

content.user_title: Build Express microservices with best practices
content.value_statement: Backend code becomes inconsistent and hard to maintain without clear patterns. This skill provides comprehensive guidelines for layered architecture, error handling, validation, and testing for Node.js/Express/TypeScript microservices.
actual_capabilities: Create layered architecture with routes, controllers, services, and repositories
Implement BaseController pattern with consistent error handling
Validate input using Zod schemas with type inference
Set up Sentry error tracking and performance monitoring
Write unit and integration tests with Jest
limitations: Does not generate complete project scaffolding
Does not deploy or run the application

use_cases.title: Learn Express patterns
use_cases.description: Understand the layered architecture and how to organize routes, controllers, services, and repositories for maintainable Express applications.

use_cases.title: Define team conventions
use_cases.description: Establish consistent patterns across microservices for error handling, validation, configuration, and testing.

use_cases.title: Modernize Express codebase
use_cases.description: Refactor routes with business logic into proper controller and service layers with dependency injection.

prompt_templates.title: Create new endpoint
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new route, controller, service, and repository for a [RESOURCE_NAME] feature. Include Zod validation schema and Sentry error tracking. Follow the BaseController pattern.

prompt_templates.title: Add validation
prompt_templates.prompt: Add Zod validation to [ENDPOINT_PATH]. Create a validation schema with type inference for the request body. Handle validation errors with proper HTTP status codes.

prompt_templates.title: Set up error tracking
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up Sentry integration for [SERVICE_NAME]. Include instrument.ts initialization, BaseController error handling, and performance monitoring for database queries.

prompt_templates.title: Refactor routes
prompt_templates.scenario: Moving business logic from routes to proper layers
prompt_templates.prompt: Refactor [ROUTE_FILE] to separate business logic from routing. Extract to controller and service layers with dependency injection. Add error handling and validation.

output_examples.input: Create a user service with repository pattern and Sentry error tracking
output: UserService - Business logic for user operations

best_practices: Keep routes thin - delegate all business logic to controllers and services
Use Zod for type-safe validation with automatic TypeScript inference
Capture all errors to Sentry with meaningful context and tags
anti_patterns: Never put business logic directly in route handlers
Never use process.env directly - use unifiedConfig for type safety
Never swallow async errors without proper try-catch and error propagation

faq.question: What is the recommended project structure?
faq.answer: Use layered architecture: routes for routing, controllers for request handling, services for business logic, repositories for data access.

faq.question: How do I validate user input?
faq.answer: Use Zod schemas with type inference. Define schemas in validators/ directory and use schema.parse() in controllers.

faq.question: How do I handle errors consistently?
faq.answer: Extend BaseController which provides handleError method with Sentry integration. Throw custom error types with proper HTTP status codes.

faq.question: How do I configure the application?
faq.answer: Use unifiedConfig pattern - type-safe configuration object loaded from config.ini with fallback to environment variables.

faq.question: What testing framework should I use?
faq.answer: Use Jest for unit and integration tests. Mock repositories and services. Target 70%+ code coverage for unit tests.

faq.question: How is this different from the official Express docs?
faq.answer: This skill provides opinionated patterns for enterprise microservices including Sentry, Zod, Prisma, and consistent error handling.
